creator: tkellerer@mgm-edv.de
text:
When "fixing" files with the FixCRLF task, a file which does not have an EOL
marker at all (e.g. one single line without EOL or EOF) the resulting file will
have an EOL marker. 

The manual only talks about "replacing" existing EOL markers but not about
adding a marker if no marker is found. Either the documentation should be
updated, or the task itself should be modified to not add the EOL marker if none
was present in the original file

creator: mbenson@apache.org
text:
<fixcrlf> has many options that should allow you to set up the behavior you 
want.  In particular, check out "fixlast" as well as "eof" and "eol".

creator: tkellerer@mgm-edv.de
text:
I'm using fixlast="true" eol="lf" tab="remove" tablength="4"
but the file with the single line (no EOL no EOF in the file) ends up with a LF
at the end after converting.

fixlast="true" is the default, and it means that the last line in the file, if 
it has no line terminator, will be modified so that it has one.  If you use 
fixlast="false", your file (which is a single, non-terminated line) should not 
be "fixed" in this fashion.
